In this day and age, the Catholic Church finds itself at a crossroads, its once steadfast flock beginning to waver. The reasons for this, I believe, lie within the Church's unyielding stance on matters that have evolved with time. The institution has always been steadfast in its views on matters such as same-sex marriage, abortion, and birth control. These views, while firm and rooted in tradition, are not always in tune with the shifting sentiments of the modern world.

The Church's rigid stance on such issues has caused some to question its relevance and has led many to seek solace elsewhere. The younger generations, in particular, are turning away from the Church because they do not share its views on these subjects. The Church's opposition to abortion, for instance, can be a barrier for those who believe in the right to choose. Similarly, its stance against same-sex marriage can be a hurdle for those who wish to celebrate their love openly and legally.

I am not advocating for the complete abandonment of these traditional views, but rather for a more nuanced approach that can accommodate the diverse beliefs and values of its followers. The Church's insistence that priests dedicate their lives to God, forsaking worldly pleasures and attachments, is a noble mission. However, it is not without its drawbacks. The Church's ban on marriage for priests, for example, can lead to feelings of isolation and loneliness, which may not be conducive to the well-being of the clergy.

The Church's history is filled with tales of its leaders, both good and bad, and it is impossible to say with certainty whether a more permissive stance on marriage and female ordination would have prevented the scandals that have shaken the Church's foundations. It is a complex issue, one that cannot be simplified into a single solution. However, it is clear that the Church must engage with these questions openly and honestly, for the sake of its future.

Well, now.

Me, personally, I ain't got no problem with that here.

Seems to me like it's not somethin' one can just choose, like a hat or a drink. Born that way, or whatever. Ain't no choice in the matter.

So, I reckon it's high time we stop holdin' folks accountable for somethin' they can't help, like the color of their eyes or the slope of their nose. Same goes for the way they're drawn to others. It's just the way they are, like the land or the weather. Ain't right to say one can and one can't, just 'cause they're different.

Now, I ain't sayin' I've give this here topic much thought. But I know what I know. And it seems to me like it's wrong to say a man can wed a woman, but two folks of the same stripe can't. Just don't make no sense.

And the federal government? They got their hands full with the big stuff, like keepin' us safe and all. Ain't their place to meddle in folks' private lives and decisions. It's like a judge tryin' to teach a fly how to fly. Just don't work that way.

So, leave them be. They're just folks, same as the rest of us. Born that way, and they shouldn't be punished for it. That's all there is to it.

I reckon that legalizing gay marriage is a notion that bears consideration, even if some see it as a threat to traditional unions. The arguments against it are many, yet they pale in comparison to the simple truth that love is love, regardless of whom it embraces. Many believe that homosexual couples are an abomination, a perversion of nature, but this is a stance born of ignorance and fear, not fact. The children of such unions, they say, will be raised in a shadow, their moral compass skewed by the unorthodox nature of their parents. But what of the countless studies that have shown no difference in the success of these unions compared to their heterosexual counterparts? The idea that gay couples will raise their children to be flawed, broken, is a fallacy. The role of a parent is not defined by their sexual orientation but by their love, guidance, and the values they instill in their children. The government, too, should not be a arbiter of such intimate matters. It is a matter of civil rights, of equality under the law. To deny one group these rights is to perpetuate segregation, separate but unequal. The federal government should step in, not to impose its will, but to ensure that all citizens are treated as such, regardless of who they choose to love. The moral high ground is not the exclusive domain of any one religion or culture. It is a shared responsibility, a collective effort to create a society that values compassion, understanding, and equality. To deny the rights of others based on their sexual orientation is to deny the very essence of what it means to be American.

Well, first off, I tend the pharmacy over the summer, just like I tend to the dying in the night. Now, Jus' cause somethin' is illegal don't mean it ain't got its uses. I've seen the likes of oxycodone and vicodin run through here, and they're as beneficial as they are controlled. But I'd say, no, I'd say we shouldn't be just tossin' it out there for the public, like a pack of wild dogs. No, no, but for medicinal purposes? Absolutely, I'd say yes. Just 'cause a drug is illegal don't make it less so. It's not beneficial, no sir.

You see, there's a world of drugs out there, like a pack of wolves waitin' to be let loose. Oxycodone, vicodin, percocets, they're all just as dangerous as the next. But we use 'em 'cause they've got a purpose. And if you deny that purpose just 'cause there's a stigma 'round marijuana, well, that's like lettin' a good dog starve. You should embrace its benefits, I reckon.

Now, I ain't sayin' it's the same as alcohol, but neither is it nothin' like heroine or cocaine. It's just... different. But that doesn't mean it can't be used responsibly. See, we just gotta get rid of that taboo, that stigma. Get rid of the image of it bein' this evil, horrible thing. Then, maybe, just maybe, folks can start usin' it responsibly, for themselves and for those who needs it. But no, not all at once, like a flood. We gotta let it in gradual, like a slow burnin' fire.

Well, the church has seen a shift in the twenty-first century. It's not as rigid as it once was. When I was younger, I'd go every Sunday, dressed in cute little dresses and matching shoes, seeing all my friends in the same attire. Now, they've introduced a teenager's mass, cut down to thirty minutes, and the dress code has relaxed significantly. People show up in beachwear during summer, families come late, and even the morning masses have seen a casual turn. People wear jeans and khakis now, which, to be honest, is quite practical but far removed from the pristine outfits of old. As for the church's politics or the scandals involving priests, I don't know the ins and outs, but I don't think changes like allowing female priests or married priests would have prevented the pedophilia accusations. Men who are married can still be attracted to children, and it's not just a matter of being allowed or not. It's a matter of wanting to serve the church and potentially not being suited for it. There are other faiths that allow marriage, so those who want to practice their faith and be married should consider other paths. I believe the attraction to children is often genetic and not entirely a result of upbringing. You can't change someone's genetics through marriage, and if they know about it and cover it up, that's shameful, but I think not all instances were known. Other than that, I have no further thoughts on the matter.

It was all well and good at first, I suppose. But with the echoes of September eleventh still ringing in our ears, we found ourselves in a land far from our shores, waging war on a premise that would soon unravel like a cheap tapestry. The Iraq war, a specter that haunts our collective consciousness, was a pretext, a mirage that led us astray. The Bush administration, with its litany of falsehoods, weaved a web of deceit, asserting that Saddam Hussein's regime was a threat, that weapons of mass destruction lurked within his grasp. Yet, the truth was as elusive as the morning mist, and the arm of justice has yet to reach out and grasp the Bush administration's neck.

Colin Powell, once a voice of authority, now echoes in the chambers of shame, confessing his doubts, his misgivings. He, like many, believed the lies, the half-truths, the deceptions. The Constitution, a sacred text, was trampled upon, its words twisted, its intent derided. The Bush administration, it seems, entered office with a dark purpose, a vengeance that burned like a fever, a desire to expand, to control.

The war drags on, a festering wound on the face of humanity. Withdrawal, a thought that sends a shiver down the spine, would be akin to leaving a child in the dark, a lamb in the jaws of a wolf. Civil war, a specter that looms large, would take its toll, a harvest of blood and tears. The coalition, a motley crew of nations, would step into the breach, but can they restore order in a land where the very fabric of government dissolves like sand between our fingers?

The interim government, a fragile construct, crumbles under the weight of its own instability. The Prime Minister, a shadow of his former self, struggles to maintain control over the political process, a raging river that threatens to sweep him away. The Parliament, a fractious body, is but a reflection of the chaos that reigns. And the radicals, those who once fought against us, now hold sway, a testament to the turmoil that grips the heart of Iraq.

None of this is the world we wanted to see. Yet, it is the world we inhabit, a land of shadows and uncertainty.

I did just as the wind does, in a breath. Aye, there's the matter of the Iraq War. I reckon it's become a point of contention, like a bone between two hounds. The war, it wasn't declared by Congress, you see. It was a matter of retribution, a strike against them who we figured planted the seeds of the eleven's horror. Now, I ain't one to keep track of such things, but I know we're there to build a democracy, to mold 'em in our image. Oil, too, plays its part, but I think it's a fool's errand. They're a people with a different way, and we're trying to force our hand upon them. It's like trying to bend a river, it only serves to create a flood. We should withdraw, let's not prolong their agony and our own. It's a tricky thing, this war. It's not fair, but it's a fact. We should let them find their own way, not force our own upon them. It's a long, arduous road they'll have to walk, but it's their path, not ours.

I don't see fit to make it so, for the state to declare it legal, or even to legalize it at all. I believe the churches should have their say, as the Constitution itself stands witness to the separation of church and state. It is plainly stated, and I believe any attempt to wield power over it would be tantamount to defying what has been written in stone. In the eyes of those who seek to make it illegal, it seems they are imposing one belief over another, as the majority of Catholics and Christians are against it, save for a few pockets like Boston. I don't see it as the government's place to decide what is legal and illegal for the churches. The separation of church and state has been a cornerstone of our Constitution, a beacon for religious tolerance. To add an amendment on this matter would be a contradiction to what is already in place, and quite possibly the only amendment used to restrict the people rather than the government. It is not right. I do not believe the federal government, nor any government, should involve itself in this matter. The president's push for this amendment seems to be driven by his personal beliefs as a Catholic, revealing a preference for one religion over others. This is not a matter for the president or any government official. There is no sound reasoning behind this amendment save for personal views. It won't impact the economy, and I believe it could even have a positive impact on society. I've said my piece.

The war in Iraq... It began with a lie, a deceit woven into the very fabric of our nation's decision to march into that foreign land. The government, they said, had weapons of mass destruction, a threat to our very existence. But it was a lie, a tale spun to rouse the emotions of a people still raw from the scars of September 11th. The government, they said, would liberate the Iraqis, bring them democracy. Yet, they were not prepared, not at all.

The war was a repeat, a echo of the Vietnam War, a war of insurgents and citizen soldiers. The government, they should have known better, should have learned from the past. But they were blind, blinded by the oil, blinded by the money. They removed the government, but they were not ready for what came next, the chaos, the void of power. They tried to plant democracy, but it was a long and hard process, a process that our own country had struggled through, a struggle of tension and civil war.

And now, years later, we are still there, still dying, still trying to train the Iraqis, to teach them how to police their own country. The government, they were not prepared, not at all. They tried to deceive us, make us believe it would be a quick and easy victory. But it was not, it was a long and hard battle, a battle that was not won, not truly won.

The war in Iraq, it was a difficult decision, a decision that still weighs heavily on my mind. I would have voted for Bush, to let him finish what he started. But now, how can we abandon them? We took their government, their way of life. How can we abandon them now? But there is also the consideration, the awful consideration of the American casualties, the American blood spilled for a cause that would never truly be won.

And the oil, the oil, it was the reason, the true reason. It was all about the money, the resources. It was not about democracy, not truly. Why Iraq and not North Korea, with their weapons of mass destruction? It was the oil, the oil that fueled our decisions, that guided our hands.

Let the war end, let the peace come. But it will not be soon, not truly.

Well, now, let's see here. I reckon I've always been in favor of the notion of gay marriage. It's a personal thing, plain and simple. I think it's a matter of biology more than sociology, and denying folks the right to marry based on something they can't control seems plain inhumane to me. I've always been an advocate for it, you see.

I don't think politics or the government ought to have a say in it. It's a personal affair, not something the state or federal government needs to be involved with. Look at my neighborhood, for instance. We've got a couple of openly gay couples, and they're just like any other family. They walk their dogs, tend to their gardens, and mind their own business. It's just the way it ought to be.

Now, I've read and heard from numerous sources that there's a biological aspect to being homosexual. It's not just about growing up in a certain environment or having a certain upbringing. It's something innate, something that's been proven time and time again.

And let's talk about marriage, shall we? If a man and a woman want to get hitched, they can just up and do it without telling a soul. But if two men or two women want to do the same, it's front-page news. I think that's just wrong. Marriage should be a private matter, not something for the public or the government to dictate.

No, I don't think it's right to deny folks the right to marry because of their sexual orientation. It's a personal choice, and it's nobody else's business.

Well, I reckon once something hits the internet, it's as good as out in the open. There ain't no hiding from that. Now, as a resident assistant, I've seen firsthand what can happen when folks put things online. It ain't just the school, mind you, but anyone with a connection can see what you've written. You can't just go spewing whatever you please about blowing things up or shootings, think about it. Someone's gonna take it the wrong way. The internet's a public forum, and you can't control how people interpret your words. It's like a wildfire, once it starts, there's no telling where it'll end up.

I've seen it myself, where someone overhears something at school and goes running to the authorities. They can't just let it be, not when lives are on the line. But here's the thing, you can't tell what's real and what's just fooling around. It could be a sociology experiment gone wrong, or it could be a real threat. One time, we had someone who was overheard saying something, and when we looked into it, we found they had posted things on their Facebook that seemed serious, even if they were meant as jokes. You can't predict how people will react.

Now, I ain't saying schools should be snooping on students' social media accounts. But if something's brought to their attention, they've got a duty to take it seriously. It's about safety, plain and simple. If it's a real threat, they can't just ignore it. And as for teachers, they shouldn't be sneaking around on social media, pretending to be someone they ain't. That's just creepy. But if a student brings something to their attention, that's different. They've given them access to their online world, and it's only right they take it seriously.

So, my advice? Think before you post. Don't put things out there that you don't want people to see. Because once it's out there, it's out there. And you can't control what people think or how they react. It's like writing in the sand, you never know who might see it, or how they'll interpret it.

In the quietude of the American night, the war drags on, a relentless river of blood and sand. It was a noble purpose, once, to restore democracy to a land shrouded in tyranny. But as the years bleed into one another, the original intent fades, like a ghost in the desert sun. We wage this conflict now, not for the sake of freedom, but to prove our might, to be the unchallenged colossus of the world. And what of Motive? Who can say if the embers of our resolve were not fanned by the ghosts of old debts, the embers of George Bush Senior's enmity with Saddam Hussein? If the purpose was to bestow democracy on a land devoid of fair governance, then so be it. But if personal grievances were the true currency, then we find ourselves adrift, drunk on the blood of innocents.

We have sent our purpose into the world, like a clarion call, in the first months of this war. But now, as the years stretch on, the clarity of that purpose dissolves. This is not a war of principle, but a war of will, a stubborn refusal to admit defeat or concede defeat. We do not want to retreat, tarnished and battered, without a decisive end, a final, triumphant cry.

The war has gone on long enough. Too long. The government of Iraq must now stand on its own, as we once did. Our resources are not endless, and every dollar spent on this foreign conflict is a dollar not spent on our own war, the war against poverty, the war to heal our own lands. The roads that crumble, the schools that fail, the hospitals that lack, they are the battlegrounds of our time, and they deserve more than the crumbs we offer them.

We have spent billions, and the war is not something to be woven into the fabric of our budget, like a decoration on a grand tapestry. There are battles to be fought at home, and they need our attention, our resources, our resolve. We cannot afford to bleed on foreign soil while our own needs go unmet. For in the end, it is our own land that will bear the scars of this war, our own people who will feel the sting of our withdrawal, our own economy that will recoil from the drain of this endless struggle.

Can I inquire, perhaps, if I might clarify a matter?

I suppose the fact is, it was averted through the intervention of an individual who, by happenstance, chanced upon the information online.

Well, now, that's the crux of the matter, ain't it? If one chooses to put forth personal tidings on the internet, then it's fair to say the world may as well have a peek.

Take Myspace, for instance. You see, it's no secret that to view another's profile, one must first accept them as a "friend." It's a covenant, if you will. But once that bond is forged, it's akin to giving them a key to your own personal sanctum.

Now, it's a curious conundrum, isn't it? For we know well that by sharing our lives online, we invite a multitude of eyes to gaze upon our secrets. And who can say if any of those eyes may harbor ill intent?

I, myself, have not delved into the realms of Myspace, but Facebook, now that's a different matter. I'll wager it's akin to walking through a market square, where one can't help but catch a glimpse of the wares laid bare for all to see.

It troubles me, this knowledge that there are those who lurk in the shadows, snooping about like vultures. I've heard tales of men who, with naught but a few clicks, can unmask your true name and weave a web of deceit. It's a precarious dance, this life in the digital age.

I've come across instances where individuals in my classes, whose faces I know not, have sent me messages, knowing full well who I am. They have seen my interests laid bare, my daily schedule laid out like a map. It's a disquieting feeling, to know that one's most private thoughts are accessible to the public.

But I suppose there's a balance to be struck. For while I limit what I share, I also wish to remain connected with those I hold dear. It's a delicate line to walk, this journey through the digital frontier.

I've heard tell that in some high schools, they've forbidden students from having Myspace accounts altogether. It strikes me as a peculiar notion, that those who ought to be guiding us could dictate what we may or may not do in our personal lives.

I reckon it's a matter of privacy, and perhaps a question of power. But I'm not one to speak on such matters with any certainty. It's a world that's ever-changing, this digital realm, and we're but mere pioneers, forging our way through uncharted territories.

Damn, the world's still a godforsaken mess when it comes to how we treat each other based on our sex. It's a long road to walk, full of hard knocks and twisted paths. Men and women, we're all just trying to carve out a place for ourselves, but the game's rigged, and the deck's stacked against us.

Take, for instance, the business world. It's still a man's world, and women have to walk a mile in their shoes just to prove they're worth their salt. They've got the qualifications, the brains, and the guts, but the board won't budge, not because they're not good enough, but because society's still stuck in the dusty past. The glass ceiling's still up there, and it's not about to shatter anytime soon.

And it's not just about women. Men, too, have their own battles to fight. In fields like fashion, where the world's already got a certain image in its mind, men can't break the mold. They're met with raised eyebrows and skeptical glances. "How can a man know fashion?" they'll ask. "Isn't that a woman's thing?"

Society's mindset's like a stubborn mule, and changing it's no easy task. It's a slow, painful process, but we're making progress. Women are rising to the top, taking on CEO positions, and it's starting to click for some people. Men staying at home, raising the kids, it's not the norm, but it's becoming more accepted. They're realizing, hey, maybe the woman's the breadwinner this time around.

But the fight's not just about sex. It's about class, about where you come from. A man from a farm, with his hands calloused and his grammar rough, he's got to fight twice as hard to prove he's got what it takes. Other men, they won't look at him straight, not with his words all twisted up. It's a goddamn shame, but it's the truth.

We've come a long way, but the road's far from over. Change's a slow, steady thing, like the tide coming in. It's not about forcing it, it's about showing the good in people, the qualities that make them shine. It's about patience, about time. And hope, too. We've got to keep fighting, keep pushing, keep chipping away at the old ways. Because, dammit, we deserve better. We all do.

They didn't so much legalize it as they did decriminalize it. Knocked it down from a criminal offense, like a pebble tumbling from a mountain to a mere traffic infraction. A citation, a slap on the wrist, rather than the cuffs and the cell. As the kid put it, "a ticket's what you get now, not a trip to the lockup." And I reckon that's where the real trouble starts. Job interviews, college applications, all those future prospects tainted by a mark on your record. A stain harder to wash out than blood from the floorboards of a saloon. But there's more to it than that. Costs money, it does, to arrest someone, book 'em, feed 'em, defend 'em. And then there's the court, the lawyers, the whole circus. A municipality on the brink, how much can they afford to spend on something like this? And then there's the philosophies, the morals, the "liberal" sentiments. Denver, it's different there. More open, more money to spend on education, social programs, aid for the poor. But it ain't for everyone. Marijuana, it's not something you want everywhere, all the time. It's a tricky business, this legalization. It's like trying to tame a storm. Some folks say it's a slippery slope, others say it's long overdue. But one thing's for sure, it's a storm that's brewing. And the wind's picking up.

I would say yes, for the sake of tradition, yes, but also for the sake of adaptability, yes. A lot of the Catholic ways are as old as the hills, deeply rooted and unchanged for centuries. And I suppose tradition, well, it's like the roots of an ancient oak - it keeps us grounded. But we must also be like the willow, bending with the wind, adapting to change. Yet, there are those who cling to the doctrine like a drowning man to a splinter.

Many a Catholic believes they must attend church weekly, and they're rigid in their rituals. The Church, it seems, doesn't take kindly to those who deviate from the straight and narrow. They turn away those who aren't perfect, and those of other religions, it seems, are as unwelcome as a stranger in a strange land. My own parents, my father an Episcopalian, my mother a Catholic, they weren't allowed to marry in the Catholic Church. It's not tolerance, this, not in the least.

We're taught to love, all of us, that's a Catholic teaching. But isn't it hypocritical to preach love and then turn away those who don't fit the mold? The practice, it seems, is stuck in the past, weighed down by its own history. Yet, they persist, like a stubborn mule.

Now, about priests marrying, I think it might be a good idea. But I don't think it would stop the rotten apples from spoiling the barrel. They'd still seek out the weak, regardless of their marital status. It's not a matter of marriage, but of sin, and sin knows no priestly vows. A child is not a wife, and if a man is inclined to such darkness, he'll do it, marriage or no. Allowing priests to marry, I don't think it would change that. I think that evil, it's a beast that prowls the earth, and it will find its way into the Church, regardless.

No, I don't believe it would make a difference.

Well, I reckon I ain't decided on this here matter yet. It's a ticklish subject, it is, right smack between the separation of church and state and how to define marriage. Now, something so close to the bone, it's hard to tackle without hurtin' someone's feelings. But I do believe it's the trickiest topic we're grappling with today.

Now, see, I ain't sure if the government should be shufflin' papers for couples getting hitched, seein' as how it's a sacrament to some folks. People don't get a tax break or any special treatment just 'cause they're baptized, do they? So, if you're married, why should it matter if it's a civil union or not? It's two people, come what may. The government don't need to look into what kind of ceremony it was, just that they're united.

And gay marriage, well, it's just two people gettin' hitched, ain't it? Same as anyone else. If the states can come to a logical agreement, then I reckon we should push for it to be federal law. But amendin' the constitution just to ban it? That's like tryin' to nail Jell-O to the wall. It's just not important enough to amend the constitution, plain and simple.

No, that's not the way to go about it.

In the crucible of my upbringing, the doctrine of Christianity was my guiding light. Yet, in my journey, I found myself in the company of souls who walked a different path, and thus, the question of the legitimacy of their love has been a trial of conscience. It is a matter of profound ambiguity, for I have known many who profess such affection, and it is not for me to pass judgment on the sanctity of their union.

I hold no animosity towards these individuals, nor do I wish to see their rights curtailed. I believe that the law of the land should reflect the will of the governed, and in a nation of diverse beliefs and persuasions, it is folly to impose a singular creed upon all. The states, those independent entities forged in the fires of revolution, ought to be given the latitude to chart their own course on this matter. The president, a figure of authority but not omniscience, should not wield the power to dictate the moral compass of every state.

A state's ethos is a reflection of its people, and it is their right to determine the contours of their society. The president's tenure is but a fleeting moment in the annals of history, while the decision of the people shall endure. To impose the will of one upon many is to sow discord, and it is not in the spirit of unity that we should strive. Let the states, those bastions of individuality, decide for themselves, and respect their judgment, for they are the keepers of their own destiny.

Ah, now let's see here. What's this all about? A bulletin board, yes? A public thing, that's what it is. If you're posting on such a board, you're putting your words out there for all to see. That's just the way of it. But you're saying the school officials had no right to see such things? Well, let me tell you, if it's on the public internet, it's not just the school officials who will see it. It's anyone, anywhere. And if you're posting something that might lead to a safer school, well, I reckon that's more important than worrying about privacy.

Now, I ain't saying they should be prowling around the internet just to catch students in the act. But if they stumble upon something that could make the school safer, well, that's their job. They're responsible for the safety of those students, aren't they? And if something like Columbine happens again, well, people will be looking for answers.

But I tell you, it's a big ol' world out there on the internet. Once you've put something out there, it's there forever. You can't take it back. It's like a ghost that haunts you. So, be careful what you post, that's all I'm saying. Be careful what you put out there, because it might just bite you in the behind someday.

Well, alright then. The war in Iraq, it was a somethin' else. At first, I was all for it, you know? I mean, I was affected by September the eleventh, so I wanted to even the score, if you catch my meanin'. I'd have gone over there and made the place a real mess, just like they did to us. But I reckon we was blinded by the whole thing, didn't really think it through, just jumped in without a plan. And now, I don't know, I ain't for it no more. I don't think it's done a lick of good.

I mean, look at 'em, they're always fightin' amongst themselves. If they can't get along, how in the hell are they gonna fight with us? I don't think us being over there is gonna change a thing. I don't care what happens over there no more. Them people, they're just not human. They can't even get along with themselves, so why should we even try to change their ways? We were just hyped up, I reckon, all emotion and anger. We went in there lookin' for revenge, and the President, he was just followin' the crowd. He thought he had to declare war, and I see where he was comin' from. But we didn't have a clear idea of what we were gonna do once we got there. We should've known better, had a plan, you know? But we didn't, and that's what we got.

And now, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. They're always gonna be the same. We ain't makin' enough progress, and it's not like we can stay there forever. No way, we're just hurtin' ourselves by stayin' over there. It's time to pull out, leave 'em be. They can sort their own mess out.

In this day and age, the Catholic Church finds itself at a crossroads, its once steadfast flock beginning to waver. The reasons for this, I believe, lie within the Church's unyielding stance on matters that have evolved with time. The institution has always been steadfast in its views on matters such as same-sex marriage, abortion, and birth control. These views, while firm and rooted in tradition, are not always in tune with the shifting sentiments of the modern world.

The Church's rigid stance on such issues has caused some to question its relevance and has led many to seek solace elsewhere. The younger generations, in particular, are turning away from the Church because they do not share its views on these subjects. The Church's opposition to abortion, for instance, can be a barrier for those who believe in the right to choose. Similarly, its stance against same-sex marriage can be a hurdle for those who wish to celebrate their love openly and legally.

I am not advocating for the complete abandonment of these traditional views, but rather for a more nuanced approach that can accommodate the diverse beliefs and values of its followers. The Church's insistence that priests dedicate their lives to God, forsaking worldly pleasures and attachments, is a noble mission. However, it is not without its drawbacks. The Church's ban on marriage for priests, for example, can lead to feelings of isolation and loneliness, which may not be conducive to the well-being of the clergy.

The Church's history is filled with tales of its leaders, both good and bad, and it is impossible to say with certainty whether a more permissive stance on marriage and female ordination would have prevented the scandals that have shaken the Church's foundations. It is a complex issue, one that cannot be simplified into a single solution. However, it is clear that the Church must engage with these questions openly and honestly, for the sake of its future.

Well, now.

Me, personally, I ain't got no problem with that here.

Seems to me like it's not somethin' one can just choose, like a hat or a drink. Born that way, or whatever. Ain't no choice in the matter.

So, I reckon it's high time we stop holdin' folks accountable for somethin' they can't help, like the color of their eyes or the slope of their nose. Same goes for the way they're drawn to others. It's just the way they are, like the land or the weather. Ain't right to say one can and one can't, just 'cause they're different.

Now, I ain't sayin' I've give this here topic much thought. But I know what I know. And it seems to me like it's wrong to say a man can wed a woman, but two folks of the same stripe can't. Just don't make no sense.

And the federal government? They got their hands full with the big stuff, like keepin' us safe and all. Ain't their place to meddle in folks' private lives and decisions. It's like a judge tryin' to teach a fly how to fly. Just don't work that way.

So, leave them be. They're just folks, same as the rest of us. Born that way, and they shouldn't be punished for it. That's all there is to it.

I reckon that legalizing gay marriage is a notion that bears consideration, even if some see it as a threat to traditional unions. The arguments against it are many, yet they pale in comparison to the simple truth that love is love, regardless of whom it embraces. Many believe that homosexual couples are an abomination, a perversion of nature, but this is a stance born of ignorance and fear, not fact. The children of such unions, they say, will be raised in a shadow, their moral compass skewed by the unorthodox nature of their parents. But what of the countless studies that have shown no difference in the success of these unions compared to their heterosexual counterparts? The idea that gay couples will raise their children to be flawed, broken, is a fallacy. The role of a parent is not defined by their sexual orientation but by their love, guidance, and the values they instill in their children. The government, too, should not be a arbiter of such intimate matters. It is a matter of civil rights, of equality under the law. To deny one group these rights is to perpetuate segregation, separate but unequal. The federal government should step in, not to impose its will, but to ensure that all citizens are treated as such, regardless of who they choose to love. The moral high ground is not the exclusive domain of any one religion or culture. It is a shared responsibility, a collective effort to create a society that values compassion, understanding, and equality. To deny the rights of others based on their sexual orientation is to deny the very essence of what it means to be American.

Well, first off, I tend the pharmacy over the summer, just like I tend to the dying in the night. Now, Jus' cause somethin' is illegal don't mean it ain't got its uses. I've seen the likes of oxycodone and vicodin run through here, and they're as beneficial as they are controlled. But I'd say, no, I'd say we shouldn't be just tossin' it out there for the public, like a pack of wild dogs. No, no, but for medicinal purposes? Absolutely, I'd say yes. Just 'cause a drug is illegal don't make it less so. It's not beneficial, no sir.

You see, there's a world of drugs out there, like a pack of wolves waitin' to be let loose. Oxycodone, vicodin, percocets, they're all just as dangerous as the next. But we use 'em 'cause they've got a purpose. And if you deny that purpose just 'cause there's a stigma 'round marijuana, well, that's like lettin' a good dog starve. You should embrace its benefits, I reckon.

Now, I ain't sayin' it's the same as alcohol, but neither is it nothin' like heroine or cocaine. It's just... different. But that doesn't mean it can't be used responsibly. See, we just gotta get rid of that taboo, that stigma. Get rid of the image of it bein' this evil, horrible thing. Then, maybe, just maybe, folks can start usin' it responsibly, for themselves and for those who needs it. But no, not all at once, like a flood. We gotta let it in gradual, like a slow burnin' fire.

Well, the church has seen a shift in the twenty-first century. It's not as rigid as it once was. When I was younger, I'd go every Sunday, dressed in cute little dresses and matching shoes, seeing all my friends in the same attire. Now, they've introduced a teenager's mass, cut down to thirty minutes, and the dress code has relaxed significantly. People show up in beachwear during summer, families come late, and even the morning masses have seen a casual turn. People wear jeans and khakis now, which, to be honest, is quite practical but far removed from the pristine outfits of old. As for the church's politics or the scandals involving priests, I don't know the ins and outs, but I don't think changes like allowing female priests or married priests would have prevented the pedophilia accusations. Men who are married can still be attracted to children, and it's not just a matter of being allowed or not. It's a matter of wanting to serve the church and potentially not being suited for it. There are other faiths that allow marriage, so those who want to practice their faith and be married should consider other paths. I believe the attraction to children is often genetic and not entirely a result of upbringing. You can't change someone's genetics through marriage, and if they know about it and cover it up, that's shameful, but I think not all instances were known. Other than that, I have no further thoughts on the matter.

It was all well and good at first, I suppose. But with the echoes of September eleventh still ringing in our ears, we found ourselves in a land far from our shores, waging war on a premise that would soon unravel like a cheap tapestry. The Iraq war, a specter that haunts our collective consciousness, was a pretext, a mirage that led us astray. The Bush administration, with its litany of falsehoods, weaved a web of deceit, asserting that Saddam Hussein's regime was a threat, that weapons of mass destruction lurked within his grasp. Yet, the truth was as elusive as the morning mist, and the arm of justice has yet to reach out and grasp the Bush administration's neck.

Colin Powell, once a voice of authority, now echoes in the chambers of shame, confessing his doubts, his misgivings. He, like many, believed the lies, the half-truths, the deceptions. The Constitution, a sacred text, was trampled upon, its words twisted, its intent derided. The Bush administration, it seems, entered office with a dark purpose, a vengeance that burned like a fever, a desire to expand, to control.

The war drags on, a festering wound on the face of humanity. Withdrawal, a thought that sends a shiver down the spine, would be akin to leaving a child in the dark, a lamb in the jaws of a wolf. Civil war, a specter that looms large, would take its toll, a harvest of blood and tears. The coalition, a motley crew of nations, would step into the breach, but can they restore order in a land where the very fabric of government dissolves like sand between our fingers?

The interim government, a fragile construct, crumbles under the weight of its own instability. The Prime Minister, a shadow of his former self, struggles to maintain control over the political process, a raging river that threatens to sweep him away. The Parliament, a fractious body, is but a reflection of the chaos that reigns. And the radicals, those who once fought against us, now hold sway, a testament to the turmoil that grips the heart of Iraq.

None of this is the world we wanted to see. Yet, it is the world we inhabit, a land of shadows and uncertainty.

I did just as the wind does, in a breath. Aye, there's the matter of the Iraq War. I reckon it's become a point of contention, like a bone between two hounds. The war, it wasn't declared by Congress, you see. It was a matter of retribution, a strike against them who we figured planted the seeds of the eleven's horror. Now, I ain't one to keep track of such things, but I know we're there to build a democracy, to mold 'em in our image. Oil, too, plays its part, but I think it's a fool's errand. They're a people with a different way, and we're trying to force our hand upon them. It's like trying to bend a river, it only serves to create a flood. We should withdraw, let's not prolong their agony and our own. It's a tricky thing, this war. It's not fair, but it's a fact. We should let them find their own way, not force our own upon them. It's a long, arduous road they'll have to walk, but it's their path, not ours.

I don't see fit to make it so, for the state to declare it legal, or even to legalize it at all. I believe the churches should have their say, as the Constitution itself stands witness to the separation of church and state. It is plainly stated, and I believe any attempt to wield power over it would be tantamount to defying what has been written in stone. In the eyes of those who seek to make it illegal, it seems they are imposing one belief over another, as the majority of Catholics and Christians are against it, save for a few pockets like Boston. I don't see it as the government's place to decide what is legal and illegal for the churches. The separation of church and state has been a cornerstone of our Constitution, a beacon for religious tolerance. To add an amendment on this matter would be a contradiction to what is already in place, and quite possibly the only amendment used to restrict the people rather than the government. It is not right. I do not believe the federal government, nor any government, should involve itself in this matter. The president's push for this amendment seems to be driven by his personal beliefs as a Catholic, revealing a preference for one religion over others. This is not a matter for the president or any government official. There is no sound reasoning behind this amendment save for personal views. It won't impact the economy, and I believe it could even have a positive impact on society. I've said my piece.

The war in Iraq... It began with a lie, a deceit woven into the very fabric of our nation's decision to march into that foreign land. The government, they said, had weapons of mass destruction, a threat to our very existence. But it was a lie, a tale spun to rouse the emotions of a people still raw from the scars of September 11th. The government, they said, would liberate the Iraqis, bring them democracy. Yet, they were not prepared, not at all.

The war was a repeat, a echo of the Vietnam War, a war of insurgents and citizen soldiers. The government, they should have known better, should have learned from the past. But they were blind, blinded by the oil, blinded by the money. They removed the government, but they were not ready for what came next, the chaos, the void of power. They tried to plant democracy, but it was a long and hard process, a process that our own country had struggled through, a struggle of tension and civil war.

And now, years later, we are still there, still dying, still trying to train the Iraqis, to teach them how to police their own country. The government, they were not prepared, not at all. They tried to deceive us, make us believe it would be a quick and easy victory. But it was not, it was a long and hard battle, a battle that was not won, not truly won.

The war in Iraq, it was a difficult decision, a decision that still weighs heavily on my mind. I would have voted for Bush, to let him finish what he started. But now, how can we abandon them? We took their government, their way of life. How can we abandon them now? But there is also the consideration, the awful consideration of the American casualties, the American blood spilled for a cause that would never truly be won.

And the oil, the oil, it was the reason, the true reason. It was all about the money, the resources. It was not about democracy, not truly. Why Iraq and not North Korea, with their weapons of mass destruction? It was the oil, the oil that fueled our decisions, that guided our hands.

Let the war end, let the peace come. But it will not be soon, not truly.

Well, now, let's see here. I reckon I've always been in favor of the notion of gay marriage. It's a personal thing, plain and simple. I think it's a matter of biology more than sociology, and denying folks the right to marry based on something they can't control seems plain inhumane to me. I've always been an advocate for it, you see.

I don't think politics or the government ought to have a say in it. It's a personal affair, not something the state or federal government needs to be involved with. Look at my neighborhood, for instance. We've got a couple of openly gay couples, and they're just like any other family. They walk their dogs, tend to their gardens, and mind their own business. It's just the way it ought to be.

Now, I've read and heard from numerous sources that there's a biological aspect to being homosexual. It's not just about growing up in a certain environment or having a certain upbringing. It's something innate, something that's been proven time and time again.

And let's talk about marriage, shall we? If a man and a woman want to get hitched, they can just up and do it without telling a soul. But if two men or two women want to do the same, it's front-page news. I think that's just wrong. Marriage should be a private matter, not something for the public or the government to dictate.

No, I don't think it's right to deny folks the right to marry because of their sexual orientation. It's a personal choice, and it's nobody else's business.

Well, I reckon once something hits the internet, it's as good as out in the open. There ain't no hiding from that. Now, as a resident assistant, I've seen firsthand what can happen when folks put things online. It ain't just the school, mind you, but anyone with a connection can see what you've written. You can't just go spewing whatever you please about blowing things up or shootings, think about it. Someone's gonna take it the wrong way. The internet's a public forum, and you can't control how people interpret your words. It's like a wildfire, once it starts, there's no telling where it'll end up.

I've seen it myself, where someone overhears something at school and goes running to the authorities. They can't just let it be, not when lives are on the line. But here's the thing, you can't tell what's real and what's just fooling around. It could be a sociology experiment gone wrong, or it could be a real threat. One time, we had someone who was overheard saying something, and when we looked into it, we found they had posted things on their Facebook that seemed serious, even if they were meant as jokes. You can't predict how people will react.

Now, I ain't saying schools should be snooping on students' social media accounts. But if something's brought to their attention, they've got a duty to take it seriously. It's about safety, plain and simple. If it's a real threat, they can't just ignore it. And as for teachers, they shouldn't be sneaking around on social media, pretending to be someone they ain't. That's just creepy. But if a student brings something to their attention, that's different. They've given them access to their online world, and it's only right they take it seriously.

So, my advice? Think before you post. Don't put things out there that you don't want people to see. Because once it's out there, it's out there. And you can't control what people think or how they react. It's like writing in the sand, you never know who might see it, or how they'll interpret it.

In the quietude of the American night, the war drags on, a relentless river of blood and sand. It was a noble purpose, once, to restore democracy to a land shrouded in tyranny. But as the years bleed into one another, the original intent fades, like a ghost in the desert sun. We wage this conflict now, not for the sake of freedom, but to prove our might, to be the unchallenged colossus of the world. And what of Motive? Who can say if the embers of our resolve were not fanned by the ghosts of old debts, the embers of George Bush Senior's enmity with Saddam Hussein? If the purpose was to bestow democracy on a land devoid of fair governance, then so be it. But if personal grievances were the true currency, then we find ourselves adrift, drunk on the blood of innocents.

We have sent our purpose into the world, like a clarion call, in the first months of this war. But now, as the years stretch on, the clarity of that purpose dissolves. This is not a war of principle, but a war of will, a stubborn refusal to admit defeat or concede defeat. We do not want to retreat, tarnished and battered, without a decisive end, a final, triumphant cry.

The war has gone on long enough. Too long. The government of Iraq must now stand on its own, as we once did. Our resources are not endless, and every dollar spent on this foreign conflict is a dollar not spent on our own war, the war against poverty, the war to heal our own lands. The roads that crumble, the schools that fail, the hospitals that lack, they are the battlegrounds of our time, and they deserve more than the crumbs we offer them.

We have spent billions, and the war is not something to be woven into the fabric of our budget, like a decoration on a grand tapestry. There are battles to be fought at home, and they need our attention, our resources, our resolve. We cannot afford to bleed on foreign soil while our own needs go unmet. For in the end, it is our own land that will bear the scars of this war, our own people who will feel the sting of our withdrawal, our own economy that will recoil from the drain of this endless struggle.

Can I inquire, perhaps, if I might clarify a matter?

I suppose the fact is, it was averted through the intervention of an individual who, by happenstance, chanced upon the information online.

Well, now, that's the crux of the matter, ain't it? If one chooses to put forth personal tidings on the internet, then it's fair to say the world may as well have a peek.

Take Myspace, for instance. You see, it's no secret that to view another's profile, one must first accept them as a "friend." It's a covenant, if you will. But once that bond is forged, it's akin to giving them a key to your own personal sanctum.

Now, it's a curious conundrum, isn't it? For we know well that by sharing our lives online, we invite a multitude of eyes to gaze upon our secrets. And who can say if any of those eyes may harbor ill intent?

I, myself, have not delved into the realms of Myspace, but Facebook, now that's a different matter. I'll wager it's akin to walking through a market square, where one can't help but catch a glimpse of the wares laid bare for all to see.

It troubles me, this knowledge that there are those who lurk in the shadows, snooping about like vultures. I've heard tales of men who, with naught but a few clicks, can unmask your true name and weave a web of deceit. It's a precarious dance, this life in the digital age.

I've come across instances where individuals in my classes, whose faces I know not, have sent me messages, knowing full well who I am. They have seen my interests laid bare, my daily schedule laid out like a map. It's a disquieting feeling, to know that one's most private thoughts are accessible to the public.

But I suppose there's a balance to be struck. For while I limit what I share, I also wish to remain connected with those I hold dear. It's a delicate line to walk, this journey through the digital frontier.

I've heard tell that in some high schools, they've forbidden students from having Myspace accounts altogether. It strikes me as a peculiar notion, that those who ought to be guiding us could dictate what we may or may not do in our personal lives.

I reckon it's a matter of privacy, and perhaps a question of power. But I'm not one to speak on such matters with any certainty. It's a world that's ever-changing, this digital realm, and we're but mere pioneers, forging our way through uncharted territories.

Damn, the world's still a godforsaken mess when it comes to how we treat each other based on our sex. It's a long road to walk, full of hard knocks and twisted paths. Men and women, we're all just trying to carve out a place for ourselves, but the game's rigged, and the deck's stacked against us.

Take, for instance, the business world. It's still a man's world, and women have to walk a mile in their shoes just to prove they're worth their salt. They've got the qualifications, the brains, and the guts, but the board won't budge, not because they're not good enough, but because society's still stuck in the dusty past. The glass ceiling's still up there, and it's not about to shatter anytime soon.

And it's not just about women. Men, too, have their own battles to fight. In fields like fashion, where the world's already got a certain image in its mind, men can't break the mold. They're met with raised eyebrows and skeptical glances. "How can a man know fashion?" they'll ask. "Isn't that a woman's thing?"

Society's mindset's like a stubborn mule, and changing it's no easy task. It's a slow, painful process, but we're making progress. Women are rising to the top, taking on CEO positions, and it's starting to click for some people. Men staying at home, raising the kids, it's not the norm, but it's becoming more accepted. They're realizing, hey, maybe the woman's the breadwinner this time around.

But the fight's not just about sex. It's about class, about where you come from. A man from a farm, with his hands calloused and his grammar rough, he's got to fight twice as hard to prove he's got what it takes. Other men, they won't look at him straight, not with his words all twisted up. It's a goddamn shame, but it's the truth.

We've come a long way, but the road's far from over. Change's a slow, steady thing, like the tide coming in. It's not about forcing it, it's about showing the good in people, the qualities that make them shine. It's about patience, about time. And hope, too. We've got to keep fighting, keep pushing, keep chipping away at the old ways. Because, dammit, we deserve better. We all do.

Well,
They didn't so much legalize it as they did decriminalize it. Knocked it down from a criminal offense, like a pebble tumbling from a mountain to a mere traffic infraction. A citation, a slap on the wrist, rather than the cuffs and the cell. As the kid put it, "a ticket's what you get now, not a trip to the lockup." And I reckon that's where the real trouble starts. Job interviews, college applications, all those future prospects tainted by a mark on your record. A stain harder to wash out than blood from the floorboards of a saloon. But there's more to it than that. Costs money, it does, to arrest someone, book 'em, feed 'em, defend 'em. And then there's the court, the lawyers, the whole circus. A municipality on the brink, how much can they afford to spend on something like this? And then there's the philosophies, the morals, the "liberal" sentiments. Denver, it's different there. More open, more money to spend on education, social programs, aid for the poor. But it ain't for everyone. Marijuana, it's not something you want everywhere, all the time. It's a tricky business, this legalization. It's like trying to tame a storm. Some folks say it's a slippery slope, others say it's long overdue. But one thing's for sure, it's a storm that's brewing. And the wind's picking up.

I would say yes, for the sake of tradition, yes, but also for the sake of adaptability, yes. A lot of the Catholic ways are as old as the hills, deeply rooted and unchanged for centuries. And I suppose tradition, well, it's like the roots of an ancient oak - it keeps us grounded. But we must also be like the willow, bending with the wind, adapting to change. Yet, there are those who cling to the doctrine like a drowning man to a splinter.

Many a Catholic believes they must attend church weekly, and they're rigid in their rituals. The Church, it seems, doesn't take kindly to those who deviate from the straight and narrow. They turn away those who aren't perfect, and those of other religions, it seems, are as unwelcome as a stranger in a strange land. My own parents, my father an Episcopalian, my mother a Catholic, they weren't allowed to marry in the Catholic Church. It's not tolerance, this, not in the least.

We're taught to love, all of us, that's a Catholic teaching. But isn't it hypocritical to preach love and then turn away those who don't fit the mold? The practice, it seems, is stuck in the past, weighed down by its own history. Yet, they persist, like a stubborn mule.

Now, about priests marrying, I think it might be a good idea. But I don't think it would stop the rotten apples from spoiling the barrel. They'd still seek out the weak, regardless of their marital status. It's not a matter of marriage, but of sin, and sin knows no priestly vows. A child is not a wife, and if a man is inclined to such darkness, he'll do it, marriage or no. Allowing priests to marry, I don't think it would change that. I think that evil, it's a beast that prowls the earth, and it will find its way into the Church, regardless.

No, I don't believe it would make a difference.

Well, I reckon I ain't decided on this here matter yet. It's a ticklish subject, it is, right smack between the separation of church and state and how to define marriage. Now, something so close to the bone, it's hard to tackle without hurtin' someone's feelings. But I do believe it's the trickiest topic we're grappling with today.

Now, see, I ain't sure if the government should be shufflin' papers for couples getting hitched, seein' as how it's a sacrament to some folks. People don't get a tax break or any special treatment just 'cause they're baptized, do they? So, if you're married, why should it matter if it's a civil union or not? It's two people, come what may. The government don't need to look into what kind of ceremony it was, just that they're united.

And gay marriage, well, it's just two people gettin' hitched, ain't it? Same as anyone else. If the states can come to a logical agreement, then I reckon we should push for it to be federal law. But amendin' the constitution just to ban it? That's like tryin' to nail Jell-O to the wall. It's just not important enough to amend the constitution, plain and simple.

No, that's not the way to go about it.

In the crucible of my upbringing, the doctrine of Christianity was my guiding light. Yet, in my journey, I found myself in the company of souls who walked a different path, and thus, the question of the legitimacy of their love has been a trial of conscience. It is a matter of profound ambiguity, for I have known many who profess such affection, and it is not for me to pass judgment on the sanctity of their union.

I hold no animosity towards these individuals, nor do I wish to see their rights curtailed. I believe that the law of the land should reflect the will of the governed, and in a nation of diverse beliefs and persuasions, it is folly to impose a singular creed upon all. The states, those independent entities forged in the fires of revolution, ought to be given the latitude to chart their own course on this matter. The president, a figure of authority but not omniscience, should not wield the power to dictate the moral compass of every state.

A state's ethos is a reflection of its people, and it is their right to determine the contours of their society. The president's tenure is but a fleeting moment in the annals of history, while the decision of the people shall endure. To impose the will of one upon many is to sow discord, and it is not in the spirit of unity that we should strive. Let the states, those bastions of individuality, decide for themselves, and respect their judgment, for they are the keepers of their own destiny.

Ah, now let's see here. What's this all about? A bulletin board, yes? A public thing, that's what it is. If you're posting on such a board, you're putting your words out there for all to see. That's just the way of it. But you're saying the school officials had no right to see such things? Well, let me tell you, if it's on the public internet, it's not just the school officials who will see it. It's anyone, anywhere. And if you're posting something that might lead to a safer school, well, I reckon that's more important than worrying about privacy.

Now, I ain't saying they should be prowling around the internet just to catch students in the act. But if they stumble upon something that could make the school safer, well, that's their job. They're responsible for the safety of those students, aren't they? And if something like Columbine happens again, well, people will be looking for answers.

But I tell you, it's a big ol' world out there on the internet. Once you've put something out there, it's there forever. You can't take it back. It's like a ghost that haunts you. So, be careful what you post, that's all I'm saying. Be careful what you put out there, because it might just bite you in the behind someday.

Well, alright then. The war in Iraq, it was a somethin' else. At first, I was all for it, you know? I mean, I was affected by September the eleventh, so I wanted to even the score, if you catch my meanin'. I'd have gone over there and made the place a real mess, just like they did to us. But I reckon we was blinded by the whole thing, didn't really think it through, just jumped in without a plan. And now, I don't know, I ain't for it no more. I don't think it's done a lick of good.

I mean, look at 'em, they're always fightin' amongst themselves. If they can't get along, how in the hell are they gonna fight with us? I don't think us being over there is gonna change a thing. I don't care what happens over there no more. Them people, they're just not human. They can't even get along with themselves, so why should we even try to change their ways? We were just hyped up, I reckon, all emotion and anger. We went in there lookin' for revenge, and the President, he was just followin' the crowd. He thought he had to declare war, and I see where he was comin' from. But we didn't have a clear idea of what we were gonna do once we got there. We should've known better, had a plan, you know? But we didn't, and that's what we got.

And now, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. They're always gonna be the same. We ain't makin' enough progress, and it's not like we can stay there forever. No way, we're just hurtin' ourselves by stayin' over there. It's time to pull out, leave 'em be. They can sort their own mess out.

In this day and age, the Catholic Church finds itself at a crossroads, its once steadfast flock beginning to waver. The reasons for this, I believe, lie within the Church's unyielding stance on matters that have evolved with time. The institution has always been steadfast in its views on matters such as same-sex marriage, abortion, and birth control. These views, while firm and rooted in tradition, are not always in tune with the shifting sentiments of the modern world.

The Church's rigid stance on such issues has caused some to question its relevance and has led many to seek solace elsewhere. The younger generations, in particular, are turning away from the Church because they do not share its views on these subjects. The Church's opposition to abortion, for instance, can be a barrier for those who believe in the right to choose. Similarly, its stance against same-sex marriage can be a hurdle for those who wish to celebrate their love openly and legally.

I am not advocating for the complete abandonment of these traditional views, but rather for a more nuanced approach that can accommodate the diverse beliefs and values of its followers. The Church's insistence that priests dedicate their lives to God, forsaking worldly pleasures and attachments, is a noble mission. However, it is not without its drawbacks. The Church's ban on marriage for priests, for example, can lead to feelings of isolation and loneliness, which may not be conducive to the well-being of the clergy.

The Church's history is filled with tales of its leaders, both good and bad, and it is impossible to say with certainty whether a more permissive stance on marriage and female ordination would have prevented the scandals that have shaken the Church's foundations. It is a complex issue, one that cannot be simplified into a single solution. However, it is clear that the Church must engage with these questions openly and honestly, for the sake of its future.

Me, personally, I ain't got no problem with that here.

Seems to me like it's not somethin' one can just choose, like a hat or a drink. Born that way, or whatever. Ain't no choice in the matter.

So, I reckon it's high time we stop holdin' folks accountable for somethin' they can't help, like the color of their eyes or the slope of their nose. Same goes for the way they're drawn to others. It's just the way they are, like the land or the weather. Ain't right to say one can and one can't, just 'cause they're different.

Now, I ain't sayin' I've give this here topic much thought. But I know what I know. And it seems to me like it's wrong to say a man can wed a woman, but two folks of the same stripe can't. Just don't make no sense.

And the federal government? They got their hands full with the big stuff, like keepin' us safe and all. Ain't their place to meddle in folks' private lives and decisions. It's like a judge tryin' to teach a fly how to fly. Just don't work that way.

So, leave them be. They're just folks, same as the rest of us. Born that way, and they shouldn't be punished for it. That's all there is to it.

I reckon that legalizing gay marriage is a notion that bears consideration, even if some see it as a threat to traditional unions. The arguments against it are many, yet they pale in comparison to the simple truth that love is love, regardless of whom it embraces. Many believe that homosexual couples are an abomination, a perversion of nature, but this is a stance born of ignorance and fear, not fact. The children of such unions, they say, will be raised in a shadow, their moral compass skewed by the unorthodox nature of their parents. But what of the countless studies that have shown no difference in the success of these unions compared to their heterosexual counterparts? The idea that gay couples will raise their children to be flawed, broken, is a fallacy. The role of a parent is not defined by their sexual orientation but by their love, guidance, and the values they instill in their children. The government, too, should not be a arbiter of such intimate matters. It is a matter of civil rights, of equality under the law. To deny one group these rights is to perpetuate segregation, separate but unequal. The federal government should step in, not to impose its will, but to ensure that all citizens are treated as such, regardless of who they choose to love. The moral high ground is not the exclusive domain of any one religion or culture. It is a shared responsibility, a collective effort to create a society that values compassion, understanding, and equality. To deny the rights of others based on their sexual orientation is to deny the very essence of what it means to be American.

Well, first off, I tend the pharmacy over the summer, just like I tend to the dying in the night. Now, Jus' cause somethin' is illegal don't mean it ain't got its uses. I've seen the likes of oxycodone and vicodin run through here, and they're as beneficial as they are controlled. But I'd say, no, I'd say we shouldn't be just tossin' it out there for the public, like a pack of wild dogs. No, no, but for medicinal purposes? Absolutely, I'd say yes. Just 'cause a drug is illegal don't make it less so. It's not beneficial, no sir.

You see, there's a world of drugs out there, like a pack of wolves waitin' to be let loose. Oxycodone, vicodin, percocets, they're all just as dangerous as the next. But we use 'em 'cause they've got a purpose. And if you deny that purpose just 'cause there's a stigma 'round marijuana, well, that's like lettin' a good dog starve. You should embrace its benefits, I reckon.

Now, I ain't sayin' it's the same as alcohol, but neither is it nothin' like heroine or cocaine. It's just... different. But that doesn't mean it can't be used responsibly. See, we just gotta get rid of that taboo, that stigma. Get rid of the image of it bein' this evil, horrible thing. Then, maybe, just maybe, folks can start usin' it responsibly, for themselves and for those who needs it. But no, not all at once, like a flood. We gotta let it in gradual, like a slow burnin' fire.

Well, the church has seen a shift in the twenty-first century. It's not as rigid as it once was. When I was younger, I'd go every Sunday, dressed in cute little dresses and matching shoes, seeing all my friends in the same attire. Now, they've introduced a teenager's mass, cut down to thirty minutes, and the dress code has relaxed significantly. People show up in beachwear during summer, families come late, and even the morning masses have seen a casual turn. People wear jeans and khakis now, which, to be honest, is quite practical but far removed from the pristine outfits of old. As for the church's politics or the scandals involving priests, I don't know the ins and outs, but I don't think changes like allowing female priests or married priests would have prevented the pedophilia accusations. Men who are married can still be attracted to children, and it's not just a matter of being allowed or not. It's a matter of wanting to serve the church and potentially not being suited for it. There are other faiths that allow marriage, so those who want to practice their faith and be married should consider other paths. I believe the attraction to children is often genetic and not entirely a result of upbringing. You can't change someone's genetics through marriage, and if they know about it and cover it up, that's shameful, but I think not all instances were known. Other than that, I have no further thoughts on the matter.

It was all well and good at first, I suppose. But with the echoes of September eleventh still ringing in our ears, we found ourselves in a land far from our shores, waging war on a premise that would soon unravel like a cheap tapestry. The Iraq war, a specter that haunts our collective consciousness, was a pretext, a mirage that led us astray. The Bush administration, with its litany of falsehoods, weaved a web of deceit, asserting that Saddam Hussein's regime was a threat, that weapons of mass destruction lurked within his grasp. Yet, the truth was as elusive as the morning mist, and the arm of justice has yet to reach out and grasp the Bush administration's neck.

Colin Powell, once a voice of authority, now echoes in the chambers of shame, confessing his doubts, his misgivings. He, like many, believed the lies, the half-truths, the deceptions. The Constitution, a sacred text, was trampled upon, its words twisted, its intent derided. The Bush administration, it seems, entered office with a dark purpose, a vengeance that burned like a fever, a desire to expand, to control.

The war drags on, a festering wound on the face of humanity. Withdrawal, a thought that sends a shiver down the spine, would be akin to leaving a child in the dark, a lamb in the jaws of a wolf. Civil war, a specter that looms large, would take its toll, a harvest of blood and tears. The coalition, a motley crew of nations, would step into the breach, but can they restore order in a land where the very fabric of government dissolves like sand between our fingers?

The interim government, a fragile construct, crumbles under the weight of its own instability. The Prime Minister, a shadow of his former self, struggles to maintain control over the political process, a raging river that threatens to sweep him away. The Parliament, a fractious body, is but a reflection of the chaos that reigns. And the radicals, those who once fought against us, now hold sway, a testament to the turmoil that grips the heart of Iraq.

None of this is the world we wanted to see. Yet, it is the world we inhabit, a land of shadows and uncertainty.
